#Text=Thomas Langton
#Text=For other people named Main Page , see Main Page ( disambiguation ) .

#Text=Thomas Langton ( died 27 January 1501 ) was chaplain to King Edward IV , before becoming successively Bishop of St David 's , Bishop of Salisbury , Bishop of Winchester , and Archbishop-elect of Canterbury .
#Text=Early life
#Text=Langton was born in Appleby-in-Westmorland , and educated by the Carmelite friars there .
#Text=He matriculated at Queen 's College , Oxford , but soon removed to Cambridge , probably to Clare Hall , on account of the plague .
#Text=In 1461 he was elected fellow of Pembroke Hall , serving as proctor in 1462 .
#Text=While at Cambridge he took both degrees in canon law , and was afterwards incorporated in them at Oxford .
#Text=In 1464 he left the university , and some time before 1476 was made chaplain to King Edward IV .
#Text=Langton was in high favour with the king , who trusted him much , and sent him on various important embassies .
#Text=In 1467 he went as ambassador to France , and as king 's chaplain was sent to treat with Ferdinand II , king of Aragon , on 24 November 1476 .
#Text=He visited France again on diplomatic business on 30 November 1477 , and on 11 August 1478 , to conclude the espousals of Edward 's daughter Elizabeth and Charles , son of the French king .

#Text=Two years later he was sent to demand the fulfilment of this marriage treaty , but the prince , now Charles VIII , king of France , refused to carry it out , and the match was broken off . [ 1 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=Meanwhile , Langton received much ecclesiastical preferment .

#Text=In 1478 he was made treasurer of Exeter , [ 2 ] prebendary of St. Decuman 's , Wells Cathedral , [ 3 ] and about the same time master of St. Julian 's Hospital , Southampton , a post which he still retained twenty years later .

#Text=He was presented on 1 July 1480 to All Hallows Church , Bread Street , and on 14 May 1482 to All Hallows , Lombard Street , City of London , also becoming prebendary of North Kelsey , Lincoln Cathedral , [ 4 ] in the next year .

#Text=Probably by the favour of King Edward V , who granted him the temporalities of the see on 21 May , Langton was advanced in 1483 to the bishopric of St. Davids ; [ 5 ] [ 6 ] the papal bull confirming the election is dated 4 July , [ 5 ] and he was consecrated in August or September . [ 5 ] Langton 's prosperity did not decline with Edward V 's deposition .
#Text=He was sent on an embassy to Rome and to France by King Richard III , who translated him to the bishopric of Salisbury by papal bull dated 8 February 1485 . [ 7 ] [ 8 ]
#Text=Langton was also elected provost of Queen 's College , Oxford , on 6 December 1487 , a post which he seems to have retained till 1495 .
#Text=He was a considerable benefactor to the college , where he built some new sets of rooms and enlarged the provost 's lodgings .
#Text=In 1493 King Henry VII transferred him from Salisbury to Winchester , [ 9 ] [ 10 ] a see which had been vacant over a year .
#Text=During the seven years that he was bishop of Winchester Langton started a school in the precincts of the palace , where he had youths trained in grammar and music .
#Text=He was a good musician himself , used to examine the scholars in person , and encourage them by good words and small rewards .

#Text=Finally , a proof of his ever-increasing popularity , Langton was elected Archbishop of Canterbury on 22 January 1501 , [ 11 ] [ 12 ] but died of the plague on the 27th , [ 11 ] before the confirmation of the deed .
#Text=He was buried in a marble tomb within ' a very fair chapel ' which he had built south of the lady-chapel in Winchester Cathedral . [ 1 ]
#Text=Death

#Text=Before his death he had given 10 pounds towards the erection of Great St. Mary 's Church , Cambridge , and in 1497 a drinking-cup , weighing 67 ounces , called the ' Anathema Cup , ' to Pembroke Hall .
#Text=This is the oldest extant hanap or covered cup that is hall-marked .

#Text=By his will , dated 16 January 1501 , Langton left large sums of money to the priests of Clare Hall , Cambridge , money and vestments to the fellows and priests of Queen 's College , Oxford , besides legacies to the friars at both universities , and to the Carmelites at Appleby-in-Westmorland .
#Text=To his sister and her husband , Rowland Machel , lands ( probably the family estates ) in Westmorland and two hundred marks were bequeathed .

#Text=An annual pension of eight marks was set aside to maintain a chapel at Appleby-in-Westmorland for a hundred years to pray for the souls of Langton , his parents , and all the faithful deceased at Appleby-in-Westmorland . [ 1 ]
